awd_titl_txt: RUI: Geometry and Complexity in the Model Theory of Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is organized around the long-standing "Algebraicity Conjecture" for groups of finite Morley rank, which arise naturally in model theory and are crucial to understanding a fundamental class of structures. The project investigates key remaining obstructions to the Algebraicity Conjecture by developing a newly found connection with approximately classical geometries. The project will also apply the existing partial solution to the Algebraicity Conjecture to establish natural limits to how much symmetry a group of finite Morley rank may encode, with the added goal of classifying those at the extreme. Additionally, the project explores the notion of "relational complexity" for finite symmetry groups, a key component of a classification theory for certain highly symmetric structures. This research addresses core problems about the complexity of certain natural families of groups and develops computational tools for further exploration. Finally, the project provides new opportunities and support for undergraduate and Masters students at California State University, Sacramento, to engage with and build skill in the model theory of groups.

The first thread of this project addresses remaining obstructions to the Algebraicity Conjecture with the goal of exploiting a connection between certain groups of small 2-rank and generically defined projective geometries. Specific aims include the elimination of a long-standing pathological configuration, a clarification of a second, and a significant expansion of the existing techniques for analyzing groups of small, but nonzero, 2-rank. The second thread of research studies permutation groups of finite Morley rank. The focus is on Borovik and Cherlin's guiding problem of classifying those groups with a sufficiently high degree of generic transitivity as being of a single form that arises naturally in projective geometry. The final thread investigates the relational complexity of finite permutation groups. The study of relational complexity is currently anchored by Cherlin's Binary Conjecture, which proposes a classification of the primitive groups of complexity 2. This project aims to broaden the scope of research on relational complexity by analyzing various natural families of permutation groups, focusing on the complexity of the symmetric and alternating groups acting on partitions. Moreover, this thread further develops algorithms and refines exiting code for computing relational complexity, with the additional goals of creating a public repository for the code and manual to support its use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
One thread of research studied permutation groups of finite Morley rank to understand the implications of high levels of generic transitivity. This thread is intertwined with actions of symmetric groups, and the outcomes of this project include several results classifying groups of finite Morley rank that carry an action of a sufficiently large symmetric group. Results were obtained both when the acted upon group is commutative and when it is not. Importantly, the project identified a new, general setting in which to carry out the analysis of actions on commutative groups that includes groups in a variety of "dimensional" contexts. The utility of this general setting is demonstrated by project results clarifying, unifying, and extending classical work on the minimal representations of symmetric and alternating groups. The project also employed these results to confirm the desired upper bound on the degree of generic sharp transitivity for a permutation group of finite Morley rank under certain, conjecturally weak, hypotheses on the structure of the group, which cover multiple cases of particular interest. A second thread of work advanced understanding of generically defined geometries of finite Morley rank, clarifying the line between them and genuine geometries while generating new questions to explore.

Additionally, the project investigated the relational complexity of finite permutation groups. A key outcome was the precise determination of the relational complexities of the symmetric and alternating groups when acting on partions where each part has size 2. Work on this problem produced techniques for exploring the complexities of actions on other types of partitions and tools for studying relational complexity generally. The project also made notable progress on several related problems about relational complexity as well as connected invariants such as notions of height and base size.

Funding for this project supported various activities at the PI's home institution of California State University, Sacramento, that provided professional development for students and faculty. Four master's students engaged in year-long research projects, resulting in two research papers thus far; two semester-long seminar series were offered for students and faculty on mathematical topics beyond the department's curriculum; and a yearly colloquium series, the Change Maker Series, was launched. The Change Maker Series has now run four consecutive years with each event connecting the University community to mathematicians working both to advance knowledge and to improve access to the discipline.


Last Modified: 01/11/2025
Modified by: Joshua Wiscons
